description: At Medium, we believe in the power of words — and we’re on a mission to bring the world’s expertise to life through memorable storytelling. Our platform rewards great writing and puts power back in the hands of readers. Medium’s subscription model means we rely on our members, not ads. We’re looking for teammates who are inspired by our mission, who are deeply thoughtful and empathetic, and who are passionate about the future of online publishing. Sound like you? Keep reading!
description_enriched: Medium is an online publishing platform that aims to bring the world's expertise to life through memorable storytelling. They offer a subscription model that relies on their members and is looking for teammates inspired by their mission. They also provide benefits, unlimited pto, healthcare, retirement, wellness, and exercise.
description_metadata_raw: At Medium, we foster an inclusive, supportive, fun, and challenging team environment. We value having a team that is made up of a diverse set of backgrounds and respect the healthy expression of diverse opinions. We embrace experimentation and the examination of all kinds of ideas through re...

company_updates.description: Don't get yourself get locked into one topic.\\n\\nSome publishing platforms want you to specialize. Their newsletter-only world works best if everyone is known for one thing. \\n\\nBut on Medium, you can write about whatever you want, whenever you want.\\n\\nPublish your theme park opinions today and your take on AI tomorrow. Here, you get to be all of yourselves.

“Writing is good for us. Writing is human. There is nothing that makes someone a writer and someone else not a writer other than the act of writing.” Sarah Olson gives the pep talk we all need in “Some Advice For Young Writers.”\\n\\nhttps://lnkd.in/ewMcYtdT

Think you need email subscribers to start publishing? You don't!\\n\\nOn Medium, you can still reach the right readers without hassling your friends and family to sign up for your newsletter.\\n\\nNeed a nudge? Here's a six-step checklist. \\n\\nhttps://lnkd.in/em8QsaEF

Unlike some other platforms (that rhyme with Grubshack), we believe you should be able to reach your readers without harvesting emails, bothering friends and family, and mastering SEO.\\n\\n"The great thing about publishing your story on Medium is that you don’t need to know anything about our recommendations system," explains Zulie. "But if you want to know more about how it all works, here’s the behind-the-scenes breakdown of the ways readers find your writing."\\n\\nhttps://lnkd.in/eVMaY3ZV
Sometimes, if you post a picture in the main post and a link in the comments, it will perform better. If you're a good fit for our Director of Marketing role, you already know this.

We're hiring at Medium! And it's a big one.\\n\\nAre you a talented marketing leader who loves both system and a craft? Are you experienced with the technical and creative sides of effective marketing?\\n\\nThen come build the blueprint with us—not just campaigns, but the systems, frameworks, and team to bring it all to life.\\n\\nhttps://lnkd.in/ebVkQd89

In Sweden, if everything’s fine, you say “there’s no cow on the ice.” If someone sneezes in Mongolia, you wish that their “mustache grows like brushwood.” In Tagalog, if you haven’t used your new air fryer yet, someone might say “baptize it already.” \\n\\nToday's Newsletter is about idioms, those "weird little tattoos" that make languages deep and unique.\\n\\nhttps://lnkd.in/ehd_86dM

"The fastest way to do a pretty good job editing is by reading your story aloud."\\n\\nOur writing challenge is in its final stretch, but it's worth reading Zulie's advice whether you're participating or not. \\n\\nWill it feel weird to read your writing out loud, to no one? Maybe.\\nWill it make your piece better? Certainly.

Is there something you can't shake? A beach you visited when you were a child? A song that you kept as a companion during a lonely stretch? A perfectly designed French tire mascot?\\n\\nChase it down. Get it in writing. Let it propel your pen. \\n\\nLife feels better when you're fascinated with it. \\n\\nIf you want, you can make this your phone background to remind you.

Just start writing.\\n\\nDon't worry about what it's for. Don't fret about who will read it. And don't imagine a multi-part content series optimized around today's trending topics.\\n\\nTake a blank page and fill it with whatever fascinates you. There will be time for editing later. \\n\\nToday, just put one word after another.
Medium's Digest is great at at matching stories to readers. So we added it to the Medium app—along with notifications to let readers know when their Digest is ready.

Can writing on the internet help you get you a better job? \\n\\nPerhaps. \\n\\nCan writing on the internet help you untangle your thoughts, \\ntest new theories,\\ndiscover the nuances of your distinct voice,\\nexperiment with form and structure,\\nfind fellowship with likeminded people,\\nand fuel your fascination with the world? \\n\\nYeah. It can.
🙏 Insights about rest, silence, and burnout from Andrea Romeo, RN BN and Elan Kesilman-Davin, PhD in today's Medium Newsletter: https://lnkd.in/ekz63CCP

"The power to choose your consequence and live with it is the most freedom we mortals can hope for.” Charles Black M.D. writes about a powerful way to reframe the idea of consequences, choice, and clarity.
Today, we're asking you to write nothing.\\n\\nFor the first day of our Write With Medium challenge, we're sitting in front of an empty page. Can you handle it? \\n\\nhttps://lnkd.in/eBz8BH3e

Things I like: fun creative prompts, daily little challenges in the spirit of the Artist's Way but easy, writing (sort of), having a fun idea at work and then just making it into a (prototype of a) thing. Introducing the June "Write with Medium" micro-challenge, sign up! https://lnkd.in/eKka24n2
When you doom scroll, you will find doom.\\nWhen you free write, you will find freedom.

You don't need a topic to start writing!\\n\\nYou'll find one. It might take a few sentences, but that brain of yours will steer you somewhere.\\n\\nToday, give yourself five minutes to write without a plan. There's no telling where it could take you.
Stop scrolling. \\n\\nStart writing.
Tiny design changes can have a huge impact. We recently tweaked our Following drop-down to include Email notifications. The result? 7x more subscribers.

The realization that today is #WorldCreativityAndInnovationDay evoked my wonderful collaborators on the journey to promote more creative, human-centered approaches to work as the core of sustainability. The UN set up WCID in 2018 to highlight the role of creativity in human development and sustainable solutions.\\n\\nSo it was particularly meaningful that Medium, where we share our work, featured our latest post, "On the Unbearable Sadness of Being Young (at Work)," in their latest newsletter. Thank you to the team (incl. Carly Gillis, Brittany Jezouit, Scott Lamb, and Brik Olson) for building a great community for these conversations. \\n\\nAnd my gratitude to the creative, innovative, global, and multidisciplinary humanity of ZeSean Ali, Denise Brouder, Ami Campbell, David Ehrenthal, Professional Certified Coach (PCC), Bahia El Oddi, Ellen Feldman, Karthik Ganesh,  Verena Hefti MBE FRSA, Hise Gibson, Sally Hamm, MD, MPH, Dr Tarek Jomaa, Nalini Kaushal, James Nicholas Kinney, Jayanth N Kolla, Kate Lee, Mel Martin, John Masko, Bess Masterson Mattei, Sylvie M Maury Ph.D, ACC, Adriana Mendes-Sheldon, Amram Migdal, Amirmasoud (Amir) Momenipour, Daven Morrison, M.D., James Naples, Arthur (Arturo) Natella, Sreedhar Potarazu, John A. Quelch, Jo-Ann Rolle, Ph.d., Demetriouse Russell, Antonio Sadaric, Susanna Sjoberg, Angela Sigal Poock, Michael Stanley, Deloris Thomas, Ph.D., MBA, Sidal Yaşar, and many others. \\n\\nYou (have) help(ed) me make sense of a topsy turvy world of work. Thank you.

company_updates.reshared_post_description: We opened up a Principal Product Designer role at Medium today and I have such huge expectations about this role and partnership it almost hurts!!! I wrote a little more about what the job looks like, what kinds of things you'd work on, what to expect from me as a manager. But it's not just about me or the work, our team is the absolute best. We are small but mighty. The most kind, super ambitious and talented, and ready to work with you. Join us. Or help us spread the word, I appreciate it. https://lnkd.in/gQcAAA_c

company_updates.reshared_post_description: This is a very good job. Very startup-y work experience but with mature traction. Very good teammates. Your boss would be one of the best people I've ever worked with. I do think social software is uniquely fun to design for because every nuance has so many implications for all the different personas. Build something for a writer and there's always a thread back to how it changes the reader's experience. \\n\\nThe ideal person is probably senior enough to be an administrator somewhere. We'll pay you what an administrator makes to build stuff instead.

A new report unearths a disturbing trend: thousands of fake academic papers, especially in cancer and Covid-19 research, flooding the system and blocking real science. In todays' Medium Newsletter: https://lnkd.in/gVZnyB5q

Big News: \\n\\nI’m the Founding Editor of Data Science Collective—The New AI & Data Science Publication on Medium.\\n\\nWhat This Means for You\\n\\nIn 2025, Data Science is everywhere. But high-quality writing about Data Science?\\n\\nMost AI/ML & Data Science content today falls into two categories:\\n🥱 Hype-driven fluff—buzzwords, shallow takes, zero real insights.\\n🥱 Dense research papers—brilliant ideas buried under unreadable jargon.\\n\\nNeither helps real practitioners.\\n\\nWith Towards Data Science departure from Medium, some of the sharpest voices in the field lost their stage.\\n\\nThat changes now.\\n\\nData Science Collective is stepping up as the new home for Data Science and AI/ML writing on Medium.\\n\\nAs Editor, my goal is simple: publish work that actually helps practitioners—no fluff, no filler, no recycled takes.\\n\\nWhat you can expect:\\n✅ Deep technical dives—real-world architectures, trade-offs, and lessons learned.\\n✅ Production case studies—not just theory, but what actually works at scale.\\n✅ No-BS AI/ML insights—if it doesn’t add value, it doesn’t get published.\\n\\nIf you’re building in AI/ML, this is your new home. \\n\\nWhether you want to share insights, stay ahead of the curve, or join the conversation—I’m here to help you get your voice heard.\\n\\nWant to contribute, share ideas, or have suggestions? \\nDrop them in the comments or DM me. 👇\\n\\nThe world needs better AI content. Let’s write it together. \\nRepost this if you're in! ♻️\\n\\nMassive thanks to Tony for the trust—thrilled to be on board!

"𝗪𝗵𝗲𝗻 𝘄𝗲 𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗻 𝗮𝘄𝗮𝘆 𝗳𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝗼𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿 𝗽𝗲𝗼𝗽𝗹𝗲’𝘀 𝗽𝗮𝗶𝗻, 𝘄𝗲 𝗱𝗲𝗻𝘆 𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝘀𝗵𝗮𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗵𝘂𝗺𝗮𝗻𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗿𝗲𝗷𝗲𝗰𝘁 𝗮𝗻 𝗼𝗽𝗽𝗼𝗿𝘁𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘁𝘆 𝘁𝗼 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗻 𝗶𝗻𝘁𝗼 𝘄𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝗻𝗲𝗰𝘁𝘀 𝘂𝘀. 𝗟𝗼𝘀𝘀 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗴𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗳 𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝘂𝗻𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗮𝗹 𝗵𝘂𝗺𝗮𝗻 𝗲𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲𝘀. 𝗜𝘁 𝗷𝘂𝘀𝘁 𝗳𝗲𝗲𝗹𝘀 𝘀𝗮𝗳𝗲𝗿 𝘁𝗼 𝗶𝗻𝘀𝘂𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝗼𝘂𝗿𝘀𝗲𝗹𝘃𝗲𝘀 𝗳𝗿𝗼𝗺 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝗿𝘀𝗵 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗹𝗶𝘁𝘆, 𝘄𝗵𝗲𝗻 𝗶𝘁 𝗵𝗮𝗽𝗽𝗲𝗻𝘀 𝘁𝗼 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝗲𝗹𝘀𝗲, 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗶𝘁 𝗰𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱 𝗯𝗲 𝘂𝘀.\\n\\n𝗔𝗻𝗱 𝗮𝘁 𝘀𝗼𝗺𝗲 𝗽𝗼𝗶𝗻𝘁, 𝗶𝘁 𝘄𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝗯𝗲."\\n\\nThis is an excerpt from a new piece I wrote and published on Medium titled, 'Grief Takes a Village.' While grief support and education have come a long way over the years, the reality is we still live in a culture that struggles to sit with people in their pain without looking away or trying to fix it. And grief needs to be witnessed—not fixed.\\n\\nOver the past nearly two weeks, as fires have ravaged homes, businesses, and entire lives & livelihoods in the Los Angeles area, this concept has shown up in the form of bright-siding (a term I first learned while training with David Kessler, FACHE): "It's just stuff." "You can rebuild." "At least you got out safely." In these impossibly hard moments, what people really need is validation and acknowledgement: "This absolutely sucks." "I'm sorry this is happening." "I wish you didn't have to go through this."\\n\\nOur discomfort-averse society loves a good comeback story. They love to praise "resilience" and "overcoming" and "moving on" from hardship. The problem is, this leaves no room to acknowledge the stories of people who are struggling, who are getting through without getting over, who are moving forward instead of moving on. It leaves no room to hold space for the "messy middle" (shout-out to Brené Brown for this terminology), and the reality and nuance of life & loss. And it overlooks a central truth of grief: it is a journey, not a destination.\\n\\nIn grief, and in life...we're all just walking each other home.\\n\\n#grief #griefsupport #griefeducation #griefawareness

Mark Zuckerberg has always been good at communicating big moments: Mobile, Messaging, Video, AI, and recently Free Expression. Whether you like or hate the actual news, the framework for these big announcement moments is worth studying.\\nI worked directly with Mark Z for 8+ years running communications at Facebook. In my current role as GP at Coatue, I got a ton of questions about this, so I looked back at my past experiences and created a “big moment” announcement framework that anyone can use.\\nI call this “big moment” communication framework the S.W.I.M Framework (as in sink or S.W.I.M). It’s key is that it’s both broad and specific, it is for both internal and external audiences and it is both aspirational and prescriptive.\\nI’m hopeful the S.W.I.M Framework will be useful to you as you plan your 2025 strategy or pivot. S.W.I.M. is just as important an internal framework for action as it is an external framework for communication.\\nWould love to hear your feedback.

Valuable insights here from Elizabeth Spiers for anyone who aspires to write better—especially if they're writing opinion pieces. Plus Scott Galloway on the male loneliness epidemic, Jessica Steier, DrPH, PMP on raw milk and more.\\n\\n➡️ https://lnkd.in/e-ijkR5u

Several years ago, while I was finishing my masters thesis and also working as the editor of a Medium publication, I told Tony Stubblebine that we should start a new Medium publication dedicated to academic writing. The pitch was that Medium is the perfect place for academics to publish and reach new readers, that the academic publishing system is terribly broken and a bit elitist, that the average thesis gets read by just a handful of people, that the best writing languishes away in Google docs and un-submitted essays by smart students!\\n\\nToday, I published a story on the Medium Blog with an intro to academic writing on Medium, and I'm working with a team at Medium to get more academic writing in front of Medium's smart community of readers. A "life is pretty cool" moment, for sure. If you're doing something academia-related--we're defining this loosely, as faculty, students, or staff--and want to learn more about how Medium might help you (or your students!) share ideas, reach out, I'd love to talk to you about it. That academics@medium.com email at the end of the story actually just forwards to my inbox. \\n\\nhttps://lnkd.in/ejgtNkuB

This week, on Beyond the Thesis With Papa PhD I have the great pleasure of having as my guest Tony Stubblebine, CEO of Medium, to talk about how academics and scientists in general can find their audience in an extremely noisy media ecosystem.\\n\\nReaching out to non-academic audiences and sharing scientific knowledge outside the walls of the lab is more and more important for academics and the exponential multiplication of communication channels has not helped reduce the noise, making the task that much harder.\\n\\nWith Tony, I will try to explore what avenues and best practices the scientific community can rely on to best reach its different audiences.\\n\\nJoin us and take part in this important discussion!
Insights from art historian Christopher P Jones about the duct tape banana, plus Avi Siegel on doing and Chris Ferrie on "bad ideas." \\n\\nFrom today's Medium Newsletter: https://lnkd.in/eYxFe9QF

Have you seen the lineup for Medium Day this year? If you haven’t, check it out on MediumDay.com. It’s a full day of (free!) talks from our incredible community.\\n\\nMedium is a writing platform, but our community is made up of all kinds of people — writers, yes, but also professors, scientists, technologists, political strategists, artists, designers, entrepreneurs, and more — sharing their knowledge on Medium. On Medium Day, they come together in one (virtual) place. If you attend, we promise you’ll learn something new.

Today’s the day — we’re expanding the Medium Partner Program to 77 new countries! Country expansion is the most requested change to the Partner Program. To everyone who has emailed us, messaged us on social media, or shared feedback to ask for this over the last couple of years: thank you.
